tossups.question: Iron crossties can be seen emerging from the base of one section of this building, which contains the Almond Door and the Doors of the Canonici. A lantern on the roof of this building is topped by a gilt copper ball that may have been finished by Michelozzo (mee-ke-LOT-so) di Bartolommeo. Emilio De Fabris won a competition to design this building's modern façade, which features alternating bands of red, green, and white marble. After designing a set of bronze doors for a nearby building, Andrea Pisano oversaw the construction of Giotto's Campanile next to this building. Four stone chains and a double shell design eliminated the need for flying buttresses in part of this building, which Ghiberti lost a competition to engineer. For 10 points, name this building whose massive octagonal dome was built by Filippo Brunelleschi.
tossups.formatted_answer: Florence Cathedral [or the Duomo of Florence; or Duomo di Firenze; or Cathedral of Saint Mary of the Flower; or Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore; prompt on the Duomo with "Where?"]
tossups.answer: Florence Cathedral [or the Duomo of Florence; or Duomo di Firenze; or Cathedral of Saint Mary of the Flower; or Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore; prompt on the Duomo with "Where?"]

tossups.question: This vector quantity is orthogonal to the gradient of angular velocity by Ferraro's law of isorotation. A corresponding "tension" is equal to this quantity dotted with the gradient vector, all applied to this quantity. This vector quantity's surface integral is constant by the "frozen-in theorem." This vector quantity is proportional to the Alfvén (ALF-vane) velocity. It's not current density, but terms involving this quantity are added to the Navier-Stokes equations in a formalism that describes plasmas. This vector quantity gives rise to an energy density equal to its square divided by twice the permeability of free space. Charge times velocity crossed with this quantity gives the Lorentz force on a particle in the absence of an electric field. Teslas are the SI unit for - for 10 points - what vector quantity denoted "B?"
tossups.formatted_answer: magnetic field strength [or B-field until "B" is read]
tossups.answer: magnetic field strength [or B-field until "B" is read]

tossups.question: In this decade, the Fumifugium (foom-if-OOG-ee-um) was published, which called for greater vegetation to be planted to combat air pollution. That book was written by John Evelyn in this decade, during which Venner's Rising led to the repression of the Fifth Monarchists. Sir John Lawrence helped distribute food during an event in this decade that was documented in Nathaniel Hodges's Loimologia (loh-moh-LOH-gee-ah). The Dutch navy captured the HMS Royal Charles during the Raid on the Medway in this decade as part of the Second Anglo-Dutch War. Mayor Thomas Bloodworth was criticized for inaction during an event in this decade, which occurred after another calamity chronicled in a "journal" by Daniel Defoe. Samuel Pepys's journal chronicled an event in this decade that began at a bakery on Pudding Lane. For 10 points, name this decade of the Great Plague and Great Fire of London.

Most visitors to this landmark start from a point named for the volunteer Charlie Turner before going through the hunting ground of a mountain lion named P-22 in the Berlin Forest. A once-lost part of this landmark was sold by Dan Bliss on eBay in 2005, after which it was repainted by the artist Bill Mack. Tom LaBonge petitioned Garmin to redirect satnav systems away from this landmark, instead directing some users to the nearby Ovation shopping mall. A 1978 replacement of this landmark with an all-steel structure was partly funded by Hugh Hefner. This Beachwood Canyon landmark stands on land owned by Griffith Park. This landmark located on Mount Lee, high in the Santa Monica hills, originally promoted a housing developed with the suffix "LAND." For 10 points, name this Los Angeles landmark that represents a West Coast film industry.
tossups.formatted_answer: The Hollywood Sign [accept the Hollywoodland Sign; prompt on Griffith Park]
tossups.answer: The Hollywood Sign [accept the Hollywoodland Sign; prompt on Griffith Park]

tossups.question: A 32-year-old atheist created by this author tells her mother, "Malebranche was right: we are not our own light." This author's essay "The Fiction Writer and His Country" quotes St. Cyril of Jerusalem's statement on a "dragon...by the side of the road," which also opens a story this author titled for an Eddie Green song. This author created a character who has "been believing in nothing ever since I was born"; that man seduces Hulga, takes her wooden leg, and stuffs it into his valise of Bibles. This author created a man who tells a woman, "No pleasure but meanness," after she cries, "You've got good blood!" In that story by this author, a grandmother murmurs, "Why you're one of my babies," to her killer, the Misfit. For 10 points, name this American author of "Good Country People" and "A Good Man is Hard to Find."
tossups.formatted_answer: Flannery O'Connor [Mary Flannery O'Connor]
tossups.answer: Flannery O'Connor [Mary Flannery O'Connor]

tossups.question: A council convened by a monarch of this name prepared 102 disciplinary canons, which Pope Sergius I refused to sign. That monarch with this name married a Khazarian woman after escaping exile in Cherson (KAIR-sahn) and convened the Quinisext Council. The second emperor of this name, whose second reign concluded the Heraclian (huh-RACK-lee-un) dynasty and was followed by the Twenty Years' Anarchy, was known as "Rhinotmetus" (rai-not-MAY-tohs) after his nose was cut off. Another emperor with this name agreed to the Treaty of Eternal Peace with Khosrow I (kohs-ROW the first) and was alleged to be able to detach his head in the Secret History of Procopius. The Corpus Juris Civilis law code was compiled under an emperor of this name, whose general, Belisarius, helped end the Nika riots. For 10 points, give this name of two Byzantine emperors, the first of which ordered the rebuilding of the Hagia Sophia (AI-uh sof-EE-uh).
tossups.formatted_answer: Justinian [or Justinian I; or Justinian the Great; or Flavius Petrus Sabbatius Iustinianus; or Justinian II; or Justinian Rhinotmetus; or Justinianus or Iustinianus or Ioustinianos in place of "Justinian"; do not accept "Justin"]
tossups.answer: Justinian [or Justinian I; or Justinian the Great; or Flavius Petrus Sabbatius Iustinianus; or Justinian II; or Justinian Rhinotmetus; or Justinianus or Iustinianus or Ioustinianos in place of "Justinian"; do not accept "Justin"]

tossups.question: A type of this property is effectively checked for each Fourier mode separately in von Neumann's (NOY-manz) criterion. For a type of this property to hold, the number of poles of a characteristic function must equal the number of encirclements of a critical point, by Nyquist's criterion. If orbits remain in a neighborhood of the point, fixed points have this property's Lyapunov (lee-AP-un-ov) type. All eigenvalues being negative corresponds to a point having this property's "exponential" type. If the potential energy is minimal, this property is possessed by a physical equilibrium point. This property is notably not possessed by a system in which one a fluid of higher density overlies one of lower density, named for Rayleigh and Taylor. For 10 points, name this property possessed by physical systems for which small perturbations decay to zero over time.
tossups.formatted_answer: stability [or stable or numerically stable or Lyapunov stability or von Neumann stability criterion or Nyquist's stability criterion]
tossups.answer: stability [or stable or numerically stable or Lyapunov stability or von Neumann stability criterion or Nyquist's stability criterion]

tossups.question: In the foreword of this novel's second edition, its author claimed that humans "are given free will in order to choose between insanity on the one hand and lunacy on the other." This novel's author included the chapter "Quantity, Quality, Morality" in a book of essays titled for this novel Revisited. This novel is usually cited as the pessimistic counterpart to a novel by its author in which Will Farnaby is shipwrecked on Pala. This novel opens by describing "a squat grey building of only thirty-four stories" displaying the motto "community, identity, stability." George Orwell claimed that this novel's author had plagiarized from the novel We in its depiction of the Bokanovsky process. Helmholtz Watson is exiled by Mustapha Mond in this novel set in the year 632 After Ford. For 10 points, name this dystopian novel by Aldous Huxley.
tossups.formatted_answer: Brave New World
tossups.answer: Brave New World

tossups.question: This essay's author was apparently unaware of similar contemporary discussions prompted by Johann Möhsen ("YO-han MUR-sen") at the "Wednesday Society." This essay's author describes hearing the officer say "Do not argue – drill!" and the tax collector say "Do not argue – pay!" This is the most famous essay from a debate prompted by a question as to whether the clergy should be required to oversee weddings, given by Johann Friedrich Zöllner ("YO-han FREED-rick ZURL-ner") in the Berlinische Monatsschrift ("bare-LIN-ish-er mon-AT-shrift"). This essay praises Frederick II for reducing state paternalism, leading to the "cultivation of... minds." This essay proposes the motto "sapere aude," ("sah-PAIR-ay OW-day"), or "dare to know," after suggesting "man's emergence from his self-incurred immaturity" as an answer to the title question. For 10 points, name this Immanuel Kant essay that defines an 18th-century period of intellectual flourishing.
tossups.formatted_answer: "What is Enlightenment?" [or "Answering the Question: What Is Enlightenment?" or "Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?" or "Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?"]
tossups.answer: "What is Enlightenment?" [or "Answering the Question: What Is Enlightenment?" or "Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?" or "Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?"]

tossups.question: Note to players: The answer to this tossup is an attribute of a specific person, such as "Abraham Lincoln being tall." Helvidius denied that this attribute always applied to its bearer, leading Jerome to write a treatise titled for it. To answer a question about how this attribute will be maintained, a messenger speaks of the "power of the Highest" "overshadowing" its holder. A pun about this attribute likely inspired the name of the legendary Roman soldier Pantera. Both Jerome and Origen highlight the fact that contemporary Ebionites did not believe in this trait by discussing their heterodox translation of the term "almah." By calling its bearer Aeiparthenos, the Second Council of Constantinople reinforced one of a group of four Catholic dogma that also include its subject's Assumption, Immaculate Conception, and Divine Motherhood. For 10 points, mainstream Christians believe that Jesus did not have a human biological father due to what trait of his mother?
tossups.formatted_answer: the virginity of Mary, the mother of Jesus [accept answers indicating the doctrine that Mary was a virgin, or indicating Mary's perpetual virginity; accept any mention of the virgin birth of Christ]
tossups.answer: the virginity of Mary, the mother of Jesus [accept answers indicating the doctrine that Mary was a virgin, or indicating Mary's perpetual virginity; accept any mention of the virgin birth of Christ]

tossups.question: In a work in this genre, a character watches a board game for five years after performing a Cesarean section with his sword to save a prince. Before performances of works in this genre, a chanter lifts the script and places it on a pedestal. In another work in this genre, a boy nicknamed "Hard Luck" agrees to abandon his love for a woman after drinking at a teahouse with her; in that work in this genre, various people attempt to buy out the courtesan Azuma's contract. A work in this genre ends with Tokubei and Ohatsu performing the title action in the Wood of Tenjin. Plays in this genre such as The Battles of Coxinga (cok-SING-uh), The Uprooted Pine, and The Love Suicides at Sonezaki were written by a master of this genre, Chikamatsu Monzaemon. For 10 points, name this Japanese form of puppet theater.
tossups.formatted_answer: bunraku [or ningyo joruri; accept Japanese puppet theater or equivalents indicating using puppets until read; prompt on jidaimono or historical romances; prompt on sewamono or domestic romances; prompt on drama, plays, or theater until "plays" is read]
tossups.answer: bunraku [or ningyo joruri; accept Japanese puppet theater or equivalents indicating using puppets until read; prompt on jidaimono or historical romances; prompt on sewamono or domestic romances; prompt on drama, plays, or theater until "plays" is read]

tossups.question: When holding one quantity constant, this equation can be applied to distinguish the ping-pong and sequential mechanisms. The coefficients alpha and alpha-prime can be added to this equation to model the effects of an inhibitor. A quasi-steady-state approximation was used to derive this equation by Briggs and Haldane. One constant in this equation divides kcat (kay cat) to give an efficiency measure. The negative reciprocal of a constant used in this equation is the x-intercept of a Lineweaver-Burk plot. When the Hill coefficient is equal to one, this equation can be used to model noncooperative binding. The constant Km (kay sub em) is used in this equation to represent the substrate concentration at half of the maximum reaction rate denoted by Vmax. For 10 points, name this equation that calculates the rate of enzyme reactions.
tossups.formatted_answer: Michaelis-Menten equation [or Michaelis-Menten kinetics; or Lineweaver-Burke until mentioned; prompt on Hill equation until Hill is read]
tossups.answer: Michaelis-Menten equation [or Michaelis-Menten kinetics; or Lineweaver-Burke until mentioned; prompt on Hill equation until Hill is read]

tossups.question: A paper by Bernhofen and Brown "directly tested" a theory of this thinker with Japanese data. Though not Keynes, Joseph Schumpeter said that a focus on abstract models was this thinker's "vice." This thinker's work inspired the book The Production of Commodities by Means of Commodities by Piero Sraffa, who supported "neo-" versions of this economist's idea. Technological development is usually central to models based on a theory developed by this thinker, in which comparisons to autarky are often made. The Heckscher-Ohlin model builds on a theory developed by this thinker in which one agent has a lower relative marginal cost of production. In Principles of Political Economy and Taxation, this thinker discussed the trade of English cloth and Portuguese wine. For 10 points, what economist developed the theory of comparative advantage?
tossups.formatted_answer: David Ricardo [accept Neo-Ricardianism]
tossups.answer: David Ricardo [accept Neo-Ricardianism]

tossups.question: Geoffrey Rush played this artist in a biopic titled Final Portrait. This artist created portraits of a man he encouraged to have an affair with his wife, the Japanese philosopher Isaku Yanaihara. This artist's injury from a drunk driver may have inspired his sculpture, The Leg. Henri Cartier-Bresson took a blurred photo of this artist in a manner resembling an adjacent statue. In 2015, London's National Portrait Gallery staged a portrait show that featured this artist's painting of his wife titled Bust of Annette. A pharmacy cart inspired a sculpture by this artist of a woman atop a chariot. A possible portrait of this artist's brother Diego is combined with seven tall figures with extremely long legs in The Forest. For 10 points, name this Swiss sculptor of Italian descent, best-known for his skinny, solitary figures such as Walking Man.
tossups.formatted_answer: Alberto Giacometti
tossups.answer: Alberto Giacometti

tossups.question: (Note to moderator: read answerline carefully.) After listening to one of these events, Patty Murray wondered "who's saying what I would say if I was there?" and ran for higher office. During one of these events, a softball question from Alan Simpson was answered with "it would be an intellectual feast." At one of these events in 2006, a man claimed "no specific recollection" of being a member of the organization Concerned Alumni of Princeton. Orrin Hatch read from The Exorcist at one of these events, at which another man denied ever talking about Long Dong Silver or asking who put a pubic hair on his can of Coke. That one of these events in 1991 was compared to a "high-tech lynching" by a man who was hoping to succeed Thurgood Marshall. The Senate Judiciary Committee holds, for 10 points, what events, including one in which Anita Hill accused Clarance Thomas of sexual harassment?
tossups.formatted_answer: confirmation hearings of Supreme Court Justices [or nomination hearings for potential Supreme Court Justices; or Supreme Court nominees' hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee; accept "SCOTUS" in place of "Supreme Court"; or confirmation hearings of Clarence Thomas or Robert Heron Bork or Samuel Anthony Alito Jr.; prompt on partial answers; prompt on Congressional hearings; do not accept answers mentioning executive offices, such as Cabinet positions]
tossups.answer: confirmation hearings of Supreme Court Justices [or nomination hearings for potential Supreme Court Justices; or Supreme Court nominees' hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee; accept "SCOTUS" in place of "Supreme Court"; or confirmation hearings of Clarence Thomas or Robert Heron Bork or Samuel Anthony Alito Jr.; prompt on partial answers; prompt on Congressional hearings; do not accept answers mentioning executive offices, such as Cabinet positions]

tossups.question: In one form of this technique, one aims for a multiplicity of observations, or MoO, of four, to avoid excessively damaging the sample. To avoid overmodeling, a randomly-sampled portion of the output of this technique is used to calculate R-free. One method of preparing samples for this technique involves growing them in an auxotrophic strain to incorporate selenomethionine, which allows the use of MAD to solve the phase problem. The Patterson function in this technique equals the electron density function convolved with its inverse. The structure of penicillin was discovered by Dorothy Hodgkin using this technique. Bragg's Law forms the basis of this technique by relating the spacing of refracting planes to the incident angle. For 10 points, name this technique that uses Röntgen radiation to determine the structure of periodic materials.
tossups.formatted_answer: x-ray crystallography [or x-ray diffraction]
tossups.answer: x-ray crystallography [or x-ray diffraction]

tossups.question: Two travelers meet an innkeeper in a void as part of an "Homage to Diderot in Three Acts" by this author. A self-insert of this author thinks of the name Agnes after seeing a woman wave at her swimming instructor in another novel. This author wrote about how a Scandinavian publisher thought his novel The Farewell Party was pushing an anti-abortion message in an essay detailing his inspiration by Hermann Broch. That essay lays out "sixty-three words" that this author found meaningful to his work and forms part of The Art of the Novel. This author's expulsion from the Communist Party inspired a novel in which Ludvik declares that "optimism is the opium of mankind!", The Joke. A section of a novel by this author defines "words misunderstood" between Franz and Sabina. For 10 points, name this Czech author of The Unbearable Lightness of Being.
tossups.formatted_answer: Milan Kundera
tossups.answer: Milan Kundera

tossups.question: Hal Ashby's film Being There features a jazz-funk rendition of this composition's opening by Eumir Deodato (eh-you-MEER d’you-DAH-too). In the second movement of this piece, muted horns quote the plainchant "Credo." A fugal subject using every tone in the chromatic scale appears in this piece's fourth movement, which represents science. This piece closes with a B major chord in the flutes, piccolos, and violins representing humanity, which clashes with a low C in the low strings; scholarly debate persists over whether that conclusion represents this work's "World Riddle." This tone poem opens with its "nature motif," the rising half notes "C, G, C" in the trumpets, which plays during the sun-moon-earth syzygy scene at the start of 2001: A Space Odyssey. For 10 points, name this Richard Strauss tone poem based on a philosophical novel by Friedrich Nietzsche.
tossups.formatted_answer: Also Sprach Zarathustra [or Thus Spake Zarathustra; or Thus Spoke Zarathustra]
tossups.answer: Also Sprach Zarathustra [or Thus Spake Zarathustra; or Thus Spoke Zarathustra]

tossups.question: The earliest Semitic texts to be deciphered were discovered in the pyramid of King Unas and provided a spell to ward off a "mother" of these creatures. The god Atum pacified one of these creatures by placing his fingernail on its spine. That one of these creatures later became one of the forty-two assessors of Ma'at and is named Nehebkau. The Enigmatic Book of the Netherworld contains the first known depiction of a symbol depicting these creatures, used to represent a unified Ra and Osiris. Egyptian priests would spit on and "defile with the left foot" wax models of these creatures. Isis creates one of these creatures from the spittle of Ra in order to obtain his true name. One of these creatures that represents chaos attacks Ra's sun barge every night. For 10 points, Apep was a giant one of what venomous creatures?
tossups.formatted_answer: snakes [or serpents; accept dragons; prompt on ouroboros]
tossups.answer: snakes [or serpents; accept dragons; prompt on ouroboros]

tossups.question: A woman who married a man of this ethnicity wrote the book Jungle West 11 about the relationship. People of this ethnicity were the largest audience for hit songs produced on Orange Street. A man with this ethnicity got into a fight with his Swedish-born wife Majbritt (MAI-brit) Morrison prior to a riot between people of this ethnicity and Teddy Boys. The Daily Mail headline "MURDERERS: If we are wrong, let them sue us" condemned police apathy towards the racially motivated stabbing of a youth born to two people of this ethnicity, Stephen Lawrence. The Notting Hill riot was targeted at people of this ethnicity, many of whom took advantage of low fares on the Empire Windrush. A Louise Bennett Coverley poem describes "colonization in reverse" by, for 10 points, what people who migrated to the U.K. from the most populous British Caribbean colony?
tossups.formatted_answer: British Jamaicans [prompt on British; prompt on West Indian; prompt on Caribbean; prompt on Black British]
tossups.answer: British Jamaicans [prompt on British; prompt on West Indian; prompt on Caribbean; prompt on Black British]

tossups.question: A technique developed by Ugo Fano (OO-go FAN-oh) was used to prove a result about these shapes at the end of the so-called "Lost Lecture." The approximate conservation of the area of one of these shapes implies that energy is proportional to frequency, in a simple example of adiabatic invariance. If the spatial frequencies are equal and the phase shift is zero, this is the most general Lissajous (LISS-ah-zhoo) figure that results. In general, plotting velocity against displacement for a harmonic oscillator gives this shape. Points on these shapes can be expressed using the true and mean anomalies. A negative total energy corresponds to this shape in the case of an attractive inverse square force. Two points on these shapes are called the perigee and apogee. Kepler's first law states all planetary orbits follow paths shaped like, for 10 points, what conic sections?
tossups.formatted_answer: ellipses [or word forms like elliptical; antiprompt on circles; prompt on conic sections until "conic" is read; prompt on planetary orbits, asking "what mathematical shape do they follow?"]
tossups.answer: ellipses [or word forms like elliptical; antiprompt on circles; prompt on conic sections until "conic" is read; prompt on planetary orbits, asking "what mathematical shape do they follow?"]

bonuses.leadin: The case Hiibel v. Sixth Judicial District Court of Nevada extended this case by ruling that mandatory disclosure of names under reasonable suspicion is constitutional. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this case, which arose from an arrest made by police officer Martin McFadden. This case ruled that it is not unconstitutional for police to adopt "stop and frisk" procedures, which became known as this case's namesake "stop".

In Terry v. Ohio, the court that this doctrine "has its limitations". This legal doctrine prevents evidence gathered in violation of the defendant's constitutional rights from being presented in court.
The debate over the legality of "stop and frisk" procedures centers around this constitutional amendment, which prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures.

bonuses.leadin: Sally Floyd's work on the "avoidance" of this phenomenon includes her development of the "random early detection" scheme now ubiquitously used in routers. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this phenomenon. Load balancers help reduce the effects of this phenomenon, which led to the temporary collapse of the Internet in 1986.
Congestion can undesirably lead to these things being intentionally "dropped." TCP detects a latency-inducing phenomenon in which these things fail to reach the intended recipient.

Most internet congestion control is implemented via TCP, which was originally designed to complement this other protocol. 127.0.0.1 ("127 point 0 point 0 point 1") is the local host's example of this protocol's namesake "addresses."

bonuses.leadin: Salvatore Di Vittorio's completion of this composer's A major 1903 violin concerto was premiered in 2010. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this impressionistic Italian composer whose Rossini-based La Boutique fantasque and Rossiniana are referenced in a Di Vittorio overture. That overture’s opening also references this composer’s Pines of Rome.

Marie Tayau premiered this French composer's A major first violin sonata, referenced repeatedly in Proust. He featured violin in the Sanctus of a Requiem whose Pie Jesu replaces the standard Dies Irae sequence.
Franck's cyclic sonata in A was written for the wedding of this Belgian "tsar of the violin," often praised for his masterful rubato and control over his vibrato.

bonuses.leadin: Lorenzo Savoini used a long steel bench as the only piece of furniture in his set design for this playwright's Incident at Vichy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American playwright who called for artificial large trees to create a gloomy atmosphere for the play The Crucible.
This Miller play's minimalist set design consists of short stairs on either side of a single chair in front of the stone tower of a German concentration camp.

Belgian director Ivo van Hove stripped away all props in his minimalist production of this play. Alfieri narrates this Miller play set in Red Hook, in which the longshoreman Eddie is killed by his own knife after reporting Marco and Rodolpho to immigration services.

bonuses.leadin: Indentured laborers were imported to this modern-day country under its colonial governor Arthur Gordon. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, where that policy led to its current population being a third Hindu, including former prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry. Frank Bainimarama (bye-NEE-mah-RAH-mah) has led this country since a 2006 coup.
Those Indian laborers were brought to Fiji to work in producing this crop, whose namesake "cane" grew wild in Fiji.

The indentured Indian laborers were described by this term, which derives from the "agreements" underlying their work. The same term is used for Indian laborers who were similarly transported to Mauritius and parts of the Caribbean.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the career of banker John S. Reed.
parts: In 2003, Reed became chairman of this financial institution following the scandal that ousted Richard Grasso. This institution closed most of its "open outcry" pits in 2007.

In 1978, Reed allocated $8 million in emergency repairs to this building after undergraduate Diane Hartley found that it was extremely vulnerable to collapsing in high winds. This skyscraper with a 45-degree roof is built over St. Peter's Church.

Reed was the American banking industry's biggest advocate for the use of these devices, which were originally made by Docutel. Caroline Murray convinced John Sheppherd-Barron to use a four-digit pin on these devices to access remotely bank funds.

bonuses.leadin: Ilya Prigogine's ("prig-oh-ZHEEN's") far-from-equilibrium theory has been referred to as the fourth of these laws. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these laws, the first of which states the conservation of energy in terms of heat, work and internal energy.

Suggestions for a fourth law of thermodynamics include a set of statements named for this scientist, which state the equality of certain cross-coefficients. This scientist gave the first analytic solution for the 2D Ising model.

This scientist claimed that there could be no fourth law of thermodynamics because it had taken three people to formulate the first, two to formulate the second, and he alone had formulated the third. An equation named for this scientist is equivalent to the Butler-Volmer equation with "eta equals zero."

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about hunting deer in Hindu mythology. For 10 points each:
parts: In the Ramayana, Sita asks Rama to catch one of these beings named Maricha, who had disguised himself as a golden deer. Rama later fights Ravana's army of these beings in Lanka.
This man was cursed by the rishi Kindama after accidentally killing him while hunting deer. This man was born pale after his mother, Ambalika, was frightened by Vyasa's appearance.
According to some stories, Bhilla was absolved of all his sins after accidentally worshiping this god while hunting deer. He is the "destroyer" god of the Trimurti.

bonuses.leadin: Some scholars claim that the word "honorificabilitudinitatibus" in this play is an anagram that proves Francis Bacon was Shakespeare. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Shakespeare comedy, in which the King of Navarre and three attendants try to avoid women for three years in order to focus on study.

Act 5, Scene 2 of Love's Labour's Lost is the longest Shakespeare scene, based on its length in this First collection containing all but two Shakespeare plays. This 1623 book's Latin-derived name indicates that it was printed on "leaves" of paper folded once.

A debated line in Love's Labour's Lost calls black "the hue of" the "school of" this word. The "school of" this word now refers to an alleged group of atheists, such as Walter Raleigh and Kit Marlowe, whom some claim wrote Shakespeare's plays.
answers: First Folio [or Mr. William Shakespeare's Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies]
formatted_answers: First Folio [or Mr. William Shakespeare's Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies]

bonuses.leadin: Pavel Anosov created bulat in an effort to duplicate this material. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this metal that was originally created from imported wootz. Pattern welding was originally thought to have been used to create this metal because of its characteristic wavy patterns.
Bulat steel was primarily used in the swords wielded by soldiers in the army of this man, who founded the Mongol Empire.
Differential heat treatment was prominently used in sword making in this modern-day country. Traditional steel in this country was made using ironsand and refined using a low open-topped bloomery.

bonuses.leadin: The accidental discovery of this compound during an attempted synthesis of fulvalene helped spark a revolution in organometallic chemistry. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this first metallocene to be discovered, which has largely replaced tetraethyl lead as an anti-knock agent in gas.

In 1952, three groups independently discovered the "sandwich" structure of ferrocene, one of which consisted of Robert Burns Woodward and this chemist. This chemist names a red-brown coordination complex made by reacting rhodium (III) (“three”) chloride with triphenylphosphine.

Woodward and Wilkinson worked out the structure of ferrocene by observing that it underwent similar reactions to compounds with this property. Hückel's rule applies to compounds with this property, which include benzene.

bonuses.leadin: The Landed Army was an elite cavalry unit in Imperial Russia. For 10 points each:
parts: The bulk of the Landed Army was filled by kholops, who belonged to this class. This feudal peasant class was abolished in 1861 by Alexander II in the Edict of Emancipation.
The rest of the Landed Army was composed of this group of people who were the subject of the Table of Ranks and comprised a namesake "duma" abolished in 1711.
The Landed Army was formed after this 1480 battle in which Ivan III defeated the leader of the Great Horde, Akhmat Khan, to effectively end Tatar power in Russia.

bonuses.leadin: In his Twenty Verses, Vasubandhu used an example of one of these events to argue that mental objects are restricted to time and space, and used another to argue that mere appearances have causative power. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these events subject to the Zhaungzi paradox. In another story, Zhaungzi cannot tell whether he was a man experiencing one of being a butterfly, or vice versa.

Vasubandhu's anti-realist "consciousness-only" theory of phenomena opposes Buddhist atomism and Advaita Vedanta's version of this position that there is only one ultimate reality and one ultimate substance.

Vasubandhu divided the twelve nidanas of dependent origination of phenomena into the same 3-2-7 scheme as this founder of madhyamaka philosophy, who used a fourfold negation to argue for anti-realism.

bonuses.leadin: Three authors from this country collaborated on an anthology translated into English as The Book of Fantasy. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, home to a novelist who wrote of a machine that allows the title character to live with Faustine forever in The Invention of Morel.

The Book of Fantasy was edited in part by Silvina Ocampo, whose sister Victoria founded the influential magazine Sur. Victoria's villa is now a cultural center managed by this UN agency, whose creations include the Collection of Representative Works and a list of World Heritage Sites.

The unrelated Ambeth Ocampo discovered this author's unfinished novel Makamisa. This author introduced the idealized María Clara in a novel whose sequel describes Crisóstomo Ibarra disguising himself as the jeweler Simoun.
answers: UNESCO [or United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization]
José Rizal [or José Protasio Rizal Mercado y Alonso Realonda]
formatted_answers: UNESCO [or United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization]
José Rizal [or José Protasio Rizal Mercado y Alonso Realonda]

bonuses.leadin: This musician joined Tony Williams and Jaco Pastorius to form the "Trio of Doom." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this jazz fusion guitarist who led the Mahavishnu Orchestra. He titles a short track on Bitches Brew, on which he performed.

McLaughlin also played on a 1971 Miles Davis fusion album titled for A Tribute to a man of this surname. Only three photos survive of an earlier guitarist with this surname who wrote "Hellhound on My Trail" and "Cross Road Blues," both of which contributed to a legend about him.
The Mahavishnu Orchestra's first performances were as a warmup act for John Lee Hooker, who, like Robert Johnson, was a guitarist who played in this often-sorrowful genre from the southern U.S.
answers: Johnson [or A Tribute to Jack Johnson; or Robert Johnson] [Those two songs contributed to the legend that Robert Johnson sold his sold to the devil at a crossroads.]
formatted_answers: Johnson [or A Tribute to Jack Johnson; or Robert Johnson] [Those two songs contributed to the legend that Robert Johnson sold his sold to the devil at a crossroads.]

bonuses.leadin: Fragmentation caused by this process can be analyzed using DNA laddering. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process. This process of programmed cell death uses caspases to activate DNase and promote cell differentiation.

The intrinsic pathway of apoptosis is activated by the release of this protein from the mitochondria, which binds to the adaptor Apaf1. This protein is also responsible for shuttling electrons between complex III and IV.
This method is often used in conjunction with DNA laddering. This assay detects DNA fragmentation using the enzyme T·d·T tagged with a fluorochrome.
answers: TUNEL assay [terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP nick end labeling]
formatted_answers: TUNEL assay [terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase dUTP nick end labeling]

bonuses.leadin: After a failed attempt to settle Denton Country, the Utopian Icarians moved to this city in 1849, though their leader Etienne Cabet was expelled from the community here in 1856. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city where the targets of Missouri Executive Order 44 moved from Independence. The first endowment ceremony was held on the second floor of this city's Red Brick Store.

This man's eldest son stayed in Nauvoo and formed the Community of Christ, or RLDS, when the majority of the Latter Day Saints followed Brigham Young to modern Utah after this man was killed in the Carthage jail.
Seven years prior to Joseph Smith's death in Carthage, another Illinois mob killed this publisher of the Alton Observer.

bonuses.leadin: This faith's three scriptures include "The Songs for the Service," "Divine Directions," and "Tip of the Writing Brush." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this religion which venerates God the Parent, and encourages engaging in Hinokishin to sweep away "mental dusts" and attain the "Joyous Life." It is the largest religion whose founding is attributed to a woman.

Tenrikyo foundress Nakayama Miki instituted the Kagura Service performed around the Jiba, which is this kind of location whose two-word Latin name denotes its status as "center of the world." In Greco-Roman astronomy, the celestial spheres rotates about it.
Until 1945, Tenrikyo was classified among the thirteen sects of this religion, whose Ise Grand Shrine features the axis mundi-esque Heart Pillar and many subshrines for various kami.

bonuses.leadin: The lines "my sweet dear, I send cheer, all the best!" open this author's poem "To a Sick Damsel," in which each line has only three syllables. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French poet and member of Marguerite de Navarre's literary court. A Douglas Hofstadter book on the difficulties of translation is titled for the Ton Beau (tohn BO) of this poet.
Marot's own translations include one of this poet's collection Il Canzoniere (cant-zohn-YAIR-ay), in which this poet addressed Laura.

In between his own spells of imprisonment, Marot also edited the work of this poet and frequent criminal, including the collection The Testament. This author's poem "Ballad of the Ladies of Times Past" includes the oft-quoted line, "Where are the snows of yesteryear?"

bonuses.leadin: In one painting, this man is shown kissing a stranger's baby as he descends a staircase. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man whose Last Moments were painted by Thomas Hovenden. A twenty-two-panel series showing the Legend of this man was created for the Detroit Institute of Arts in 1941.

The Legend of John Brown was created by this Black painter. People file through doors labeled "New York" and "Chicago" in the first panel of a series by this painter which also contains a scene of a segregated dining room.

John Steuart Curry's depiction of Brown brandishing a bible and a rifle in the mural Tragic Prelude was inspired by the figure of God creating the Sun on this location's ceiling. Michelangelo painted The Creation of Adam for this Vatican building.
answers: John Brown [or The Last Moments of John Brown; or Legend of John Brown]
formatted_answers: John Brown [or The Last Moments of John Brown; or Legend of John Brown]

bonuses.leadin: Name these 20th-century composers who questioned the definition of music, for 10 points each:
parts: This French composer challenged the idea that music should be listened to consciously with his idea of "furniture music" that would be listened to in the background. His more conventional music includes three Gymnopédies ("zhim-no-PAY-dees") for piano.

Music was defined as "organized sound" by this modernist composer, who used "sound-masses" in works like Ionisation. This French composer wrote Density 21.5 for Georges Barrère's ("ZHORZH bah-RAIR'S") platinum flute.

This composer stated "it is the gratuitous play of a child" as one of seven criteria for music in the book Formalized Music, which includes the FORTRAN code for his music program GENDY. His Pithoprakta is based on the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution.
